Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = L(u) \\), where \\( L \\) is a differential operator. We explore the effects of applying a Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) to the function \\( u(x,t) \\) at time \\( t \\\\\\\\).

If \\( \\mathcal{F}(u(x,0)) \\) is calculated at \\( t = 0 \\) and then the solution is evolved by \\( L \\) without further intervention, will the Fourier transform of \\( u(x,T) \\), \\( \\mathcal{F}(u(x,T)) \\), be the same as evolving \\( u(x,0) \\) to \\( u(x,T) \\) first and then applying \\( \\mathcal{F} \\)?
Explanation: The evolution of the Fourier transform of \\( u(x,0) \\) under \\( L \\) might not correspond directly to the Fourier transform of the evolved state \\( u(x,T) \\) due to the properties of \\( L \\) and how it interacts with the transformation properties of the Fourier transform.
